content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.
I am unable to approve your problem can any of you tell me why?

Ok, we're there.  Approving.

Comments:

- This feels like  the community puzzle I've had to write the most code for.

- I'm glad I'm over this :D The problem is interesting, but there are so many moving parts it makes debugging very inconvenient. I suppose the detailed test cases will help a lot in this regard, but I didn't have them when I was developing :)

- I'm not sure having a different input format for both door placement (NESW) and arrow (^>v<) adds anything. As far as my code's concerned, it's just one more conversion. (if you intend to change this, my preference is on NESW)

- Not sure whether or not it happens in the test cases since in the end my code was robust wrt that, but I did wonder for some time whether or not arrows could be placed on top of another arrows. Possible impacts: internal datastructures, and ambiguity wrt the "3 live arrows per player" rule.

- Bug: constraints say doors <= 4 and turns >= 10, I think those are wrong in a few case samples.

Thanks for the turn ordering, I do think that makes it a lot clearer.

How does the "in-passing" eating rule mix with the turn phase ordering?

The current wording seems to imply cat and mouse swap positions first (phase 1), then mouse scores (phase 2), (...) then mouse is eaten (phase 4). But that's a bit weird when the "in passing" rule seems to say the mouse never reaches its destination.
I like it, but I will probably need a bit of time before I can actually implement it :)

I don't think that situation is possible. In order for a mouse to score (enter a rocket) and switch places with a cat, the cat would need to be exiting a rocket. This can't happen. A rocket is an endpoint, so a cat can't ever be exiting a rocket.

Thank you very much for taking the time to so thoroughly review. Your comments have been very helpful in improving the quality of the submission.

I have changed all the directions in the test input to NESW, as recommended. I have changed the incorrect constraints. And I have added a new statement in the Arrows section indicating placement restrictions.
As in you can't click the Approve option? Is it there but grayed-out? Or is it completely missing?
When I approve it it says 'Another in progress'

Strange. I don't know why. I recommend you file a bug with CG:

https://www.codingame.com/about/contact
I can't either. I get a red pop-up with: error (#-1) "internal error".

Not sure if either of you has submitted a problem report, but I have, so hopefully this will get some attention soon. Thanks for trying my puzzle! :-)

 - danBhentschel
I've reported the problem to codersHS@codingame.com (address given with the error message).
Oh, right, good point. Ok, so I'm out of procrastination excuses again.

Can players place an arrow on a spot where there's already one? (yes/no/who cares, not in tests)
On a mouse/cat/rocket? (I assume it's irrelevant,  but the previous question got me to wonder)

1) No. I just re-verified that the tests don't do this.

2) mouse / cat -> yes ... rocket -> no

If an arrow is placed on a mouse  or cat, it doesn't affect their current trajectory because "whenever a cat or mouse moves onto a square with an arrow, it turns to face in the direction indicated by the arrow."

Ok.

Well, my current code solves the first two test/validators, but fails on the two remaining ones.

No obvious reason why yet. I assumed 0-based indexing, X is width is E-W. Will look for more elaborate typos later.

I updated the test cases to isolate individual requirements, and I umm ... uhh ... I found a bug in my code. :-)

So I have fixed my code, and have fixed the offending test cases to correspond. Sorry for the confusion. :-)

Oh. I was cleaning up my code right now, desperately trying to find new light.

Reloading and trying again, then :)

Wow, that's a lot more tests! So now I'm passing all but:
- redirecting arrows
- eating the mice
- eating in passing
- rumble
- all out war
7:5. Sounds like progress.

Solved Redirecting arrows. That made it fail Simple battle.

So I'll have to ask explicitly because for all the times I read the statement, it doesn't actually say and it feels like my initial assumptions were wrong:

When does mouse and cat generation fit in the turn ordering?

I initially put it first because it's mostly first in the problem statement. Then I put it after mouse/cat movement, because it doesn't make that much sense to have them appear directly in the middle of the board to then crawl a single square at a time. I just finally put it last so they could be affected by arrows from the same turn (and it's the worst place for me in the current layout, since now I have to redirect the animals twice), and that's what seemed to fix the Redirecting arrows case.

(it does sound a bit crazy this way, since it looks just like it's the same as "straight first". I suppose I'm trying to get sensible answers to "does an arrow placed on turn t affect an animal entered on turn t - dist to arrow?" (I would not like: only if dist=0) and "when does animation pause?" (I would not like: twice per turn))

Animal generation can be thought of as part of #1, "All mice and cats move simultaneously". I picture doors as an infinite line of mice and cats stretching off the edges of the play field, moving forward one space each turn.

Well, that's what I got for now :)
Getting back to mouse eating then.

I have updated the problem statement a bit to hopefully make the order of events a bit more obvious. I also added a very simple new test, "One for each", that should hopefully help in debugging the timing of a turn.

100% at last.

Stupid bug was: cat only ate mouse if they shared position *and* direction. Like that could happen :)

Cleaning up my code, then I'll write something up.
